    Libya floods death toll rises above 20,000 as survivors continue searching
    There are fears up to 20,000 people have died after flooding through eastern Libya. Hope is turning to despair for residents in the city of Derna as survivors continue to wade through the rubble in search of loved ones. Questions are being raised about what could have been done to prevent the loss of life. Satellite images from before and after the floods show the levels of immense destruction. The hostilities in recent years have split the city into sections as rescue crews face a difficult task of bringing relief to as many places as possible.

    Hunter Biden, the son of Joe Biden has been formally indicted days after an impeachment inquiry was launched into the US President.

    PM Trudeau pledges GST cut for rental housing construction
    Prime Minister Justin Trudeau says Ottawa will remove GST on the construction of new rental apartment buildings, a move he first promised in 2015.   • Open

    AP PHOTOS: Satellite images show flood devastation that killed more than 11,000 in Libya
    Images taken by satellite show the physical devastation from a flood that killed at least 11,300 people in the eastern Libyan city of Derna. Two dams above Derna burst early Monday under the pressure from rain dropped by a storm. The pent-up water swept blocks of low-lying downtown Derna out to the Mediterranean Sea. Many said they heard loud explosions as the dams exploded. A flood several meters (many feet) high rolled down a mountainside into the city. Images made about 400 miles above the earth’s surface show that the storm left a brown layer of mud and dirt across the city. Untold numbers are buried under mud and debris that includes overturned cars and chunks of concrete. The death toll soared to 11,300 as search efforts continue, Marie el-Drese, secretary-general of the Libyan Red Crescent, told The Associated Press by phone Thursday. She said that an additional 10,100 had been reported missing. Health authorities previously put the death toll in Derna at 5,500. The...  ( 10 min )

    Caught unaware, whole families drowned in a matter of minutes
    The coastal city of Derna in Libya experienced severe flooding after two dams burst, leaving thousands of people displaced and searching for loved ones. Many residents were caught off guard by the flooding as there were no evacuation plans in place.     Libya seeks answers as flood deaths feared to cross 20,000
    Libyan authorities have called for an investigation into the cause of the devastating floods that have resulted in thousands of deaths in the country. The floods were triggered by a powerful storm that caused dams to burst, washing away buildings and trapping people inside. The death toll is estimated to be in the thousands, with many more people missing.  ( 44 min )

    Nasa says more science and less stigma are needed to understand UFOs
    Nasa has released findings from its yearlong study into UFOs, stating that the study of these unidentified flying objects will require new scientific techniques and a shift in perception. The study's 33-page report cautions that the negative perception surrounding UFOs hampers data collection. The overcrowded fishing trawler, carrying between 400-750 people from Pakistan, Syria, and Egypt, sank in international waters. Only 104 men survived, and 82 bodies were recovered.  ( 42 min )

    A Palestinian family in Libya, who had fled Gaza during the 1967 Arab-Israeli war, has been affected by the devastating floods in the country.     Firefighters in the United States are suing manufacturers and companies that make firefighting gear and foam, claiming that the gear contains toxic industrial compound PFAS, which is associated with health problems including cancer. Cancer has become the leading cause of death among firefighters, with the International Association of Fire Fighters attributing 66% of firefighter deaths between 2002 and 2019 to cancer.  ( 72 min )

    The city of Derna has buried thousands of people in mass graves, Libyan officials said Thursday, as search teams scoured ruins left by devastating floods and the city's mayor said that the death toll could triple or more. The deluge swept away entire families on Sunday night and exposed vulnerabilities in the oil-rich country that has been mired in conflict since its 2011 uprising.  ( 52 min )

    Axios: Favorite Biden columnist: He "should not run again in 2024"  President Biden, befitting his generation, loves newspapers and the classic columnists. David Ignatius, Tom Friedman and David Brooks top his list.   Driving the news: Ignatius, 73, a well-wired Washington Post foreign-affairs columnist who writes spy novels on the side, is out with a column (page A23 Wednesday) with the blunt headline: "President Biden should not run again in 2024."   Why it matters: Biden, 80, still sees himself as a young go-getter. Here's a respected voice he has known for 40+ years telling him that by plunging ahead, he "risks undoing his greatest achievement — which was stopping Trump."   Read more ....   Update #1: WaPo columnist argues Biden 'too old' to run again, should have stopped Hunter's 'attempts to impress clients' (FOX News)   Update #2: More Voices Call On Biden To Withdraw From The 2024 Race (Moon of Alabama)   WNU Editor: When you are a Democrat President and you lose David Ignatius.     Six Issues to Watch at the UN General Assembly 78
    WASHINGTON DC, Sep 14 (IPS) - Another UNGA (UN General Assembly High-Level Week, September 18-23, 2023) is almost here. Leaders and other senior representatives of the world body’s 193 Member States will gather again for this truly one-of-a-kind annual congregation in New York for high-stakes diplomacy and plenty of domestic political posturing.     Gabon: The End of a Dictatorship and the Beginning of Another?
    MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Sep 13 (IPS) - On 26 August, Gabon went through the motions of an election. Official results were announced four days later, in the middle of the night, with the country under curfew. Predictably, incumbent President Ali Bongo, in power since the death of his father and predecessor in 2009, was handed a third term. Fraud allegations were rife, as in previous elections. But this time something unprecedented happened: less than an hour later the military had taken over, and the Bongo family’s 56-year reign had ended. Read the full story, “Gabon: The End of a Dictatorship and the Beginning of Another?”, on globalissues.org →

    Making Nuclear Sharing Credible Again: What the F-35A Means for NATO

But when it comes to nuclear sharing, their assessments are remarkably similar. Both groups claim, either explicitly or implicitly, that American B-61 gravity bombs and the nuclear sharing arrangement as a whole are militarily obsolete and lack credibility. However, participants in the ongoing debate about the future of NATO’s nuclear deterrence posture have failed to realize that the technological and political nature of nuclear sharing is changing.     Paxton Impeachment Trial: Senators debating dismissal
    Ken Paxton's defense team is asking for a 'directed verdict', which allows the Senate jurors to vote on the dismissal of the articles of impeachment.
    At least 56 dead following nine-floor apartment inferno in Hanoi
    At least 56 people, including children, have died in an apartment building fire in Vietnam's capital Hanoi. Rescue efforts have been hampered due to the building not having emergency exits and being positioned at the end of a narrow alley. At least 70 people were rescued and nearly 40 people were injured when they jumped onto neighbouring roofs to escape the inferno. Firefighters extinguished the fire in about an hour, as footage shows the intense blaze shooting out from every floor of the building. Vietnam's Prime Minister visited the site to extend his condolences and police have detained the building's owner ahead of further investigation.
    Tough new laws for unsanctioned ADF personnel working with foreign military bodies
    Former ADF personnel could face up to 20 years behind bars if they work for foreign military bodies without approval. New legislation is set to be introduced by Defence Minister Richard Marles which will prevent sensitive defence information from being accessed by foreign militaries. It follows revelations Beijing was seeking to poach former Australian pilots to train its military last year. The Chinese recruitment scheme reportedly extended to using third parties for headhunting Western military leaders. Those working within the Five Eyes countries, the US, UK, New Zealand and Canada, will be exempt from the tough new rules.

    Russia's Missile Production is Now Beyond Prewar Levels
    DNYUZ/New York Times: Russia Overcomes Sanctions to Expand Missile Production, Officials Say  Russia has managed to overcome sanctions and export controls imposed by the West to expand its missile production beyond prewar levels, according to U.S., European and Ukrainian officials, leaving Ukraine especially vulnerable to intensified attacks in the coming months.  In addition to spending more than $40 billion providing weapons for Ukraine, the United States has made curbing Russia’s military supply a key part of its strategy to support Kyiv.  As a result of the sanctions, American officials estimate that Russia was forced to dramatically slow its production of missiles and other weaponry at the start of the war in February 2022 for at least six months. But by the end of 2022, Moscow’s military industrial manufacturing began to pick up speed again, American officials who spoke on condition of anonymity to disclose the sensitive assessment now concede.   Read more ....   WNU Editor: So much for the Western political and media narrative that we have been hearing constantly for the past year that Russia was going to run out of missiles.  On a side note.  The above New York Times post reveals something that should give everyone pause ....   .... it costs a Western country $5,000 to $6,000 to make a 155-millimeter artillery round, whereas it costs Russia about $600 to produce a comparable 152-millimeter artillery shell.   You cannot win a war if the economies of production favors your opponent.

    New Images Emerge Of The B-21
    USAF   Warzone/The Drive: B-21 Raider Seen Like Never Before In New Images   We have just been given our first side view of Northrop Grumman’s B-21 Raider stealth bomber, an aircraft that remains cloaked in secrecy.   During Air Force Chief of Staff Charles Q. Brown's speech at this year's Air & Space Forces Association's mega conference outside of Washington, D.C., the soon-to-be Chairman of the Joint Chiefs dropped two new images of the B-21 Raider. While the stealth bomber was rolled out in December of last year, it remains cloaked in secrecy. Brown, the top Air Force uniformed officer, didn't specifically reference the images in his presentation.  Up until today, only one angle of the full aircraft has been seen by the public — head-on — and in a very controlled environment at the bomber's unveiling. Aside from a close-up of the cockpit area at an angle, all imagery published since then has been from the same head-on perspective, although it has progressively shown the aircraft in more detail. Now we have our first quartering view of the flying-wing jet, which provides significant details about its design. A new head-on image also gives us a better idea of the bomber's actual size. Both images were taken at Northrop Grumman's facility at Plant 42 in Palmdale, California.   Read more ....  New Images Emerge Of The B-21   CSAF Shows Off New Images of the B-21; Raider Begins Engine Runs -- Air & Space Forces  B-21 Raider stealth bomber: New images show US Air Force’s £585m cutting-edge aircraft -- The Independent   New B-21 photos released, as engine runs begin -- Breaking Defense   New Photos Offer Rare Glimpse at US' Classified B-21 Stealth Bomber -- Sputnik

    Ukraine Launch Massive Missile Attack On Sevastapol
    BBC: Ukraine launches missile attack on Crimea  Russia says Ukraine has launched 10 missiles and three unmanned boats in an attack on the home of its Black Sea fleet in Crimea.  The attack caused a large fire at a Sevastopol shipyard which left 24 people injured, Russia said.  Moscow-installed governor Mikhail Razvozhayev claimed most of the weapons were intercepted but that two ships had been damaged.  Ukraine has strongly implied western-supplied cruise missiles were used. Unmanned vessels, known by many different names including sea drones and drone boats, operate on or below the water.  They usually have built-in explosives and cameras that feed directly back to the person controlling them.   Read more ....   WNU Editor: This attack happened on the same day that Putin was meeting Nor…

    NATO Preparing For The Biggest Military Exercises In Europe Since The Cold War
    A training exercise in Poland in May this year. Nato is pushing to transform itself from crisis response to a war-fighting alliance, prompted by the invasion of Ukraine © Artur Widak/NurPhoto/Reuters   Zero Hedge: NATO Prepares For Biggest Military Exercise Since Cold War, And Close To Russia  The upcoming Steadfast Defender NATO war drills, set for early 2024, are expected to be the biggest military exercises in Europe since the end of the Cold War, the Financial Times is reporting Monday.  At a moment the war in Ukraine grows more and more unpredictable, given neither Russia nor the West have shown any signs of backing down, the FT writes that "Nato is preparing its biggest live joint command exercise since the cold war next year, assembling more than 40,000 troops to practice how the alliance would attempt to repel Russian aggression against one of its members."  Read more ....     NATO Conducting Major Baltic Exercises Focused On Repelling Russian Attacks
    NATO: NATO navies hold annual Northern Coasts collective defence exercise in the Baltic Sea  Some 30 warships and 3,200 personnel from 14 nations will participate in the annual two-week naval exercise Northern Coasts, which starts on Saturday (9 September 2023) in the Baltic Sea, primarily off the coasts of Estonia and Latvia. Led by the German Navy, Northern Coasts is one of the biggest exercises in the region, and is focusing for the first time on high-end warfare and the collective defence of NATO Allies.   Read more ....   Update: NATO Baltic War Games Simulate Article 5 Collective Defense War With Russia (Zero Hedge)   WNU Editor: Apparently this is the first time these type of exercises are being held ....     Family of late US billionaire George Lindemann agrees to return looted artefacts to Cambodia
    In what was hailed as a “momentous” move by Cambodia, the late American pipeline businessman George Lindemann’s family “voluntarily” agreed to return 33 looted artefacts to the Southeast Asian country. According to the US Attorney's Office, the artefacts that would be returned include statues of deities, angels and demons from the 10th and 12th centuries from Koh Ker.
    White House hopeful Ramaswamy joins Trump in calling for huge government job cuts
    Vivek Ramaswamy joined a rising chorus of Republican presidential contenders in 2024 who have pledged to drastically cut the size and scope of the federal government if elected next year, calling for a "revolution" that will hold the federal bureaucracy "accountable."  ( 49 min )
    White House press secretary slams Republican impeachment inquiry against president Joe Biden as baseless
    White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre strongly criticized Republican plans to launch an impeachment inquiry against President Joe Biden. She denounced the effort as baseless and a political stunt, highlighting the lack of concrete evidence presented by Republicans. Jean-Pierre suggested that the initiative was driven by pressure from the far-right wing of the Republican Party and characterized the process as illegitimate.
    US teen, 14, charged of trying to drown Black youth in pond
    A teenager in the United States was charged allegedly for trying to drown a black teen in a Cape Cod pond in Massachusetts. The black teen alleged that while John Sheeran (14) jabbed his head into the water, another white teen laughed and called him “George Floyd” as he couldn’t breathe.
    Pakistan President Arif Alvi ‘advises’ EC to hold polls on Nov 6
    Pakistan President Arif Alvi has proposed November 6 as the date for the country's upcoming elections in a letter to the Chief Election Commissioner. The move has sparked controversy, as there are divided opinions among stakeholders on the timing of the polls. The president cited constitutional provisions giving him the authority to announce the poll date.  ( 48 min )
    White House says Iran deal is 'not ransom'
    The White House denied Wednesday that the unfreezing of $6 billion of Iranian funds to help secure the release of five US citizens was effectively a ransom payment. It's not ransom," said White House national security spokesman John Kirby, pushing back against criticism of the deal.
    Pakistan court extends Imran Khan’s remand in cipher case
    Imran Khan, the leader of the Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf (PTI) party, has had his judicial remand extended until September 26 in a cipher case. Khan and Shah Mahmood Qureshi, a former foreign minister, are accused of making public the contents of a confidential diplomatic cable. The cable was cited by Khan as proof of a US attempt to remove his government.  ( 47 min )
    Trump has been privately encouraging GOP lawmakers to impeach Joe Biden
    Former President Donald Trump dined with Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene and discussed the strategy for impeaching President Joe Biden. Trump has been closely following House Republicans' push for impeachment and has encouraged their efforts.Elise Stefanik, who briefed him on the impeachment inquiry strategy. However, Trump has not been pressuring House Speaker Kevin McCarthy regarding the impeachment inquiry into Biden.
    Former Czech Premier Andrej Babis loses case on collaborating with communist-era secret police
    Slovakia's Supreme Court has upheld a ruling dismissing a lawsuit by former Czech Prime Minister Andrej Babis against allegations of collaboration with the communist-era secret police. Babis had sued Slovakia's Institute of the Nation's Memory, which holds parts of his secret police files. The institute claims the files contain evidence that Babis was an agent, but he denies this.  ( 42 min )
    Israel strikes on Syria kill two soldiers: state media
    Israeli air strikes on Wednesday killed two Syrian soldiers and wounded six others on Syria's west coast, state media said, quoting a military source. "At exactly 17:22 this afternoon, the Israeli enemy carried out strikes... from the direction of the Mediterranean Sea targeting some of our air defence sites in Tartus," the official news agency SANA quoted the source as saying.  ( 41 min )
    Death toll from devastating floods in Libyan city passes 5,100
    At least 5,100 people have been killed in the eastern Libyan city of Derna due to massive flooding caused by Mediterranean storm Daniel. The flooding, which was the result of two dams collapsing, has left thousands missing and tens of thousands homeless. Aid workers have struggled to reach the city due to washed-out roads, making it challenging to provide assistance to those affected.  ( 67 min )
    Brazil requests US help for probes involving Bolsonaro, sources say
    Brazil has officially requested assistance from US law enforcement in investigations involving former President Jair Bolsonaro. This comes after Bolsonaro's ex-aide, Mauro Cid, agreed to cooperate with Brazilian investigators. The request aims to corroborate Cid's statements regarding his involvement in various criminal probes, including falsified vaccination records and the sale of expensive jewels. Bolsonaro, who denies any wrongdoing, is facing mounting legal troubles after losing his re-election bid.
    A fishing vessel in Greenland will try to free a cruise ship that ran aground with 206 people
    A fishing vessel owned by Greenland's government will attempt to free a luxury cruise ship that ran aground in northwestern Greenland. The passengers and crew on the stranded ship are reported to be safe and doing well. The scientific fishing vessel will try to pull the cruise ship free during high tide. The cruise ship, MV Ocean Explorer, ran aground in Alpefjord in the Northeast Greenland National Park.  ( 53 min )
    Fugitive Danelo Cavalcante arrested after two weeks on the run
    Danelo Cavalcante, a convicted murderer who escaped from a Pennsylvania prison for two weeks, terrifying people in the suburbs west of Philadelphia, was apprehended on Wednesday, Pennsylvania state police said. On August 31, he escaped from Chester County Prison, roughly 30 miles (50 kilometers) west of Philadelphia, by climbing between two walls that formed an extremely narrow corridor in the jail house yard and ascending onto the roof.
    Huge bushfire raging in central Australia comes close to popular tourist town
    A bushfire in central Australia is threatening the tourist town of Tennant Creek. Authorities have issued a "watch and act" alert for the region, indicating a heightened threat level. Tennant Creek, which is popular with travellers, is home to around 3,000 people. Changing wind conditions are posing a risk to residents, and the fire has breached containment lines to the north and south of the town.  ( 44 min )
    North Korea's Kim vows full support for Russia’s 'sacred fight' after viewing launchpads with Putin
    North Korean leader Kim Jong Un expressed his "full and unconditional support" to Russian President Vladimir Putin in Russia's "sacred fight" to defend its security interests, likely referring to the war in Ukraine. Kim also emphasized that North Korea's relationship with Russia is its top priority. The leaders met at a rocket launch facility in Siberia, highlighting their shared interests.  ( 57 min )
    US lawmaker Lauren Boebert kicked out of theatre for 'laughing, singing loudly'
    Republican US representative Lauren Boebert was asked to leave a theater performance in Denver after causing disturbance by laughing, singing, recording, and vaping. She was escorted out along with another patron after receiving several complaints. Boebert confirmed the incident on social media, admitting to enjoying the performance and pleading guilty to laughing and singing too loudly. She denied vaping but admitted to taking a photo with her cellphone, unaware that photography was not permitted.  ( 45 min )

    The OSS Society's William J. Donovan Award® Dinner
    The OSS Society's William J. Donovan Award® Dinner The OSS Society's William J. Donovan Award® Dinner, the preeminent annual gathering of the US intelligence and Special Operations communities, will be held in Washington, DC, on October 21, 2023. Corporate sponsorships are still available. Please click on this link to download the invitation: https://www.dropbox.com/scl/fi/didrkh4z4mpxkl5xkak5p/2023_Invite_FINAL.pdf?rlkey=sxg1ya3r2yixch9lkoo44a723&dl=0.  The OSS Society offers a $100 discount to OSS Society members who register online. (To become a member of The OSS OSS Society, please fill out its membership application form: https://www.osssociety.org/forms.html.) Former military personnel receive a discounted ticket price, too.     TOKYO, Japan, Sep 12 (IPS) -   1. SDGs and global governance Sustainable development is the challenge of how to build a society in which humanity can live with dignity in this global environment. The SDGs set 17 goals and 169 targets to achieve sustainable development. Goals 16 and 17 are aimed precisely at building global governance through the formation of global rules. Goal 16 lists 10 specific targets, while Goal 17 lists 19 targets.     Russia to show new diplomatic ambitions ahead of talks with North Korea’s Kim Jong Un
    North Korea's leader Kim Jong Un will meet with Russian President Vladimir Putin at an unspecified location in Russia’s Far East region later in the week. Kim Jong Un arrived in Russia on board a heavily armoured train yesterday ahead of his meeting with the Russian president. Vladimir Putin is currently attending the Eastern Economic Forum in Vladivostok which is Russia’s closest city to the North Korean border. North Korea Political Expert Dr Leonid Petrov believes the meeting between the meeting is significant for both parties and gives Russia the chance to demonstrate its new diplomatic ambition following its invasion of Ukraine. “Russia has been increasingly isolated and … it’s important to demonstrate that he (Vladimir Putin) is not just someone who is now being sought by the International Criminal Court but also supported by the neighbouring states like North Korea.”

    China's arms exports face sharp decline due to defective quality, unreliable performance: Analysts
    China's arms exports have dropped by nearly a quarter in the last decade due to poor quality and inconsistent performance. The Chinese People's Liberation Army (PLA) is plagued by low-quality weapons. China's global market share has also shrunk. Buyers are attracted by the low prices, but they face hidden costs when the gear malfunctions.  ( 48 min )
    18 Iraq police get jail terms over Sweden embassy fire
    A court in Iraq has sentenced 18 police officers to jail terms of up to three years for failing to prevent protesters from storming and setting fire to Sweden's embassy in Baghdad. The attack on the embassy was in response to the desecration of the Quran by an Iraqi refugee in Stockholm. The court found the police officers guilty of not carrying out their duties and some of them were permanently disbarred from the force.  ( 42 min )

    Hurricane Lee, a Category 3 storm, is expected to remain in open waters as it moves towards Atlantic Canada. It is located south of Bermuda and has winds of up to 115 mph. The storm is forecasted to weaken into a tropical storm and make landfall in Nova Scotia, Canada. Lee is generating dangerous surf and rip currents along the East Coast of the United States.  ( 47 min )

    Expect Higher Oil And Gas Prices This Winter
    OPEC Oil Data Show 3 Million-Barrel Shortfall on Saudi Supply Squeeze   Bloomberg: OPEC Oil Data Show 3 Million-Barrel Shortfall on Saudi Supply Squeeze  Global oil markets face a supply shortfall of more than 3 million barrels a day next quarter — potentially the biggest deficit in more than a decade — as Saudi Arabia extends its production cuts. The latest data published by OPEC show why the kingdom’s supply squeeze, amid a period of record demand, has sent oil prices surging beyond $90 a barrel in London. Riyadh announced last week it will extend an extra 1 million-barrel-a-day output reduction until the end of the year, even though markets are already tightening.  World oil inventories, having depleted sharply this quarter, are set for an even steeper drop of roughly 3.3 million barrels a day in the next three months, forecasts published in a report from the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries indicated on Tuesday.  Read more ....   Update: Oil sprints higher as OPEC report reveals Saudi Arabia cuts further (FXStreet)   WNU Editor: Pray for a warm winter.

    BBC: US releases $6bn in frozen Iran funds for prisoner swap  The US has issued a sanctions waiver for banks to transfer $6bn (£4.8bn) of frozen Iranian funds from South Korea to Qatar, paving the way for the release of five Americans held by Iran. Secretary of State Antony Blinken told Congress that the money would provide "limited benefit" to Iran as it could only be used for humanitarian trade.  He also confirmed that five Iranians detained in the US would be freed as part of the prisoner exchange deal.     10 years ago, we were turning nuclear bombs into nuclear energy. We can do it again.
    Getty Images How we turned 20,000 Soviet nukes into zero-carbon energy — and how we can do the same with some of our own. Just a decade ago, one in 10 American lightbulbs was powered by dismantled Russian nuclear weapons. That was made possible by the Megatons to Megawatts program, an agreement negotiated after the collapse of the Soviet Union to convert uranium from Russia’s nuclear weapons stockpile into fuel for US nuclear power plants. The unconventional policy was first proposed by MIT physicist Thomas Neff in a 1991 New York Times op-ed. By the time Megatons to Megawatts ran its full course from 1993 to 2013, it had eliminated about 20,000 nuclear warheads and stood out as a point of shared pride in the often jaded arms control and disarmament field. “Nearly every commercia…  ( 15 min )
